awd_titl_txt: The effect of lands surrounding fragmented landscapes: theory development and novel experimental tests
awd_abstract_narration:
Species are declining across the world. The destruction of plant and animal habitat is a well-known cause for such declines. It is less appreciated that lands surrounding remaining suitable habitats, termed "the matrix" can be important for species. Observations suggest that in many situations, these lands can be necessary for the survival of species. Understanding why these effects occur is important for advancing our knowledge on land-use change. This research will address these issues by providing novel field experiments to understand both habitat and non-habitat effects on species. The results will be used to provide solutions for mitigating the deleterious effects of habitat destruction on natural populations of species. It will also provide broader impacts to society by developing videos on the findings which will be presented to the public at a natural history museum. 

In this project, the researchers will conduct field experiments designed to elucidate effects of the matrix on populations. They will also develop theoretical models of this study system which can be applied to other similar systems in which species typically live in habitats surrounded by unsuitable lands (the matrix).  The study system consists of two species of insect herbivores that specialize on prickly pear cactus and vary in dispersal ability. The cactus plants are the suitable habitats, occurring in clumps surrounded by a variety of grass species which is the matrix. The experiments will manipulate habitat size, degree of fragmentation (number of habitats and distance between habitats) and quality of the matrix land to test how each of these factors affects the population dynamics of the subject species. The results will be used to evaluate the importance of matrix effects relative to the well-known effects of habitat loss and fragmentation. Model development will contextualize these results and will provide new solutions for predicting the effects of the matrix on connectivity and population dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Habitat loss and fragmentation are widely considered the most important near-term threats to biodiversity. As environments continue to change, the non-habitat “matrix”, or the surrounding lands in which fragments are embedded, is an increasingly dominant component of landscapes. For many species, we now know that the matrix matters for biodiversity, yet our understanding of the causes and consequences of these effects remain limited. This project provided unprecedented field experiments on the role of the matrix for populations and enhanced conceptual understanding and prediction in population and landscape models. Field experiments focused on insects that specialize on prickly pear cactus (Opuntia humifusa).

 

Our first experiment manipulated habitat loss, fragmentation, and matrix quality across landscapes to determine relative impacts on populations of the insect Chelindea vittiger. Overall, high loss, high fragmentation, and low matrix quality reduced population sizes. Effects of matrix quality were as large as that of habitat loss and greater than fragmentation. Effects were driven by matrix quality influencing survival of insects across landscapes. Our second experiment manipulated matrix quality directly surrounding habitat and across entire landscapes to test for the scale of matrix effects on Chelinidea vittiger. Population size in fragments was shaped by both patch- and landscape-scale matrix treatments. In contrast, survival rates and reproductive output depended only on the matrix directly surrounding patches. These results underscore the outsized importance of the matrix immediately adjacent to fragment edges. We also developed theoretical and spatial models for understanding matrix effects and mapping where, and the extent to which, animals may move across landscape that vary in matrix conditions. These models identify key parameters that drive the population effects of the matrix and provide a means to predict the effects of wildlife corridors, human-wildlife conflict, and other factors (e.g., roads) on movement of species across landscapes.

 

There were several broader impacts of this project. We trained four postdoctoral associates, six graduate students, three supervisory technicians, eight REU students, eight undergraduate interns, and had 28 other undergraduate volunteers. Many of these students came from unrepresented groups. We worked with local managers to enhance infrastructure at the Ordway-Swisher Biological Station where our experiments occurred by facilitating research and providing outreach events. Finally, we introduced new software for applying the models we derived, provided online tutorials of software use, ran two workshops to train participants on model applications in ecology and conservation, and worked closely with several stakeholders that applied models to conservation issues throughout the world.
